3) The school term will be extended to compensate for the missed class time

description: As part of its State of Calamity decree, Guatemala announces on March 6th that it will prevent gatherings of people and to prohibit or suspend all kinds of public performances and all kinds of meetings or events that represent a risk to health. Public shows, meetings or events scheduled for Saturday 7 and Sunday 8 March 2020 may be held without any interference, but from Monday 9 requests of authorization for any kind of event will have to be sent to the ministry.

On March 10th, Guatemala informs the population that each person or public and/or private company that wants to carry out events with more than 150 people, must ask for authorization of the activity with 48 to 72 hours of anticipation in the Health Area of their locality.

On March 10th, Guatemala declares that due to the confusion surrounding mass events, notifying the health departments will be necessary, but no authorization will be issued, because, no case of COVID-19 has been confirmed in Guatemala as of yet. Notifications must be made online 48 hours to 72 hours prior to the event.
On March 14th, Guatemala announces that starting from March 15th that all sporting events must be held behind closed doors as part of the State of Calamity.

On March 14th, Guatemala announces that all religious activities celebrating Holy Week are suspended until further notice, and meetings or groups of more than 100 people are prohibited from March 15th onwards.
On March 16th, Guatemala announces that it prohibits any type of event, regardless of the number of participants, as well as sporting, social and cultural activities.

As part of its State of Calamity decree, Guatemala announces on March 6th that it will prevent gatherings of people and to prohibit or suspend all kinds of public performances and all kinds of meetings or events that represent a risk to health. Public shows, meetings or events scheduled for Saturday 7 and Sunday 8 March 2020 may be held without any interference, but from Monday 9 requests of authorization for any kind of event will have to be sent to the ministry.
On May 7th, in San Miguel Petapa, in Guatemala, the mayor announces that only 20 people at a time will be allowed inside all markets.

On June 2nd, Guatemala activated a protocol for the phased re-opening of sports centres. A 'testing' period will last a week before actual reactivation of the sports centres. During this week, the following rules are applied:
Only prioritized athletes (1st, 2nd and 3rd line) determined by the FADN, coaches and technical support personnel will have access under a schedule.
During the sports activation phase for training processes, a schedule of 8am to 1pm will be established, with a maximum of 60 minutes per session. 
To comply with the protocol of hygiene and sanitization of entrance.
During the stay inside the facility, avoid any kind of physical contact according to the specific regulations by sport.
Wear a badge or card as well as a mask to enter and remain inside the facility.
Respect the rules of physical distance for sports and regulation of users by area.
It is prohibited to enter briefcases, bags, backpacks, as well as the use of cell phones during the training session.
Show up with sports clothes to use, towel and personal hygiene items.
No food is allowed, only a bottle with liquids will be allowed.
It is forbidden to share drinks or personal objects.
It is forbidden to spit and blow your nose inside the facility.
The use of showers, dressing rooms and drinking fountains is forbidden.
The use of air conditioners is not allowed.
Any equipment or material used during training must be disinfected before and after use.
